outcome: The Memory Market: With BCI records in chaos, a black market for old paper documents and pre-BCI identification surges. Citizens scramble to reclaim their rights and status, triggering a quiet, grassroots revolt against algorithmic control. Council infighting worsens as old manual clerks become key figures in community survival, opening a new front in the power struggle.

events.description: City residents begin trading handwritten records, physical ID cards, and personal references in street markets to access housing, food, and jobs as BCI access remains unreliable.
Long-retired clerks, once obsolete, become crucial brokers for restoring identities. Informal neighborhood committees emerge to validate and distribute proof of residency and history.
Council factions clash publicly over whether to ban or embrace the paper market. Directorate teams seize archives, while Innovators argue manual records are safer than chaotic BCI restoration.
Tensions erupt as hundreds of citizens denied by the BCI blockade service centers, demanding recognition of paper records. Scenes of confrontation and negotiation play out in public squares.
The Council announces a provisional policy recognizing hybrid manual-digital records, granting temporary rights to thousands and cementing a citizen-driven check on BCI oversight.
